user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_rmfs:
```c
int32 OS_rmfs(const char *devname)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(devname);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, devname, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * NOTE: It is likely that if the file system is mounted,
         * this call to stop the volume will fail.
         *
         * It would be prudent to first check the flags to ensure that
         * the filesystem is unmounted first, but this would break
         * compatibility with the existing unit tests.
         */
        return_code = OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl(&token);

        /* Free the entry in the master table  */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_rmfs:
#define OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_PATH_LEN,OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(lock_mode, idtype, OS_ObjectNameMatch, (void *)name, token);
}
...
int32 OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    /*
     * This is a no-op.
     *
     * Volatile volumes are just directories created in the temp dir,
     * and this will not remove the directories just in case something
     * went wrong.
     *
     * If the volume is started again, the directory will be re-used.
     */
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND (-17)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the token parameter is used as an in/out object. OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete reads token->obj_id and passes the token to OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id), which is expected to modify/unlock the object record (and may update token fields). Because the function (or callees) needs to modify the object token, the pointer must not be const, so rule 8.13 is not violated.
